title: Best Carrot Cake Cupcake Recipe - How To Make Carrot Cake Cupcakes
body: <style type="text/css">#sidepanel{transform:translateX(0);visibility:visible;content-visibility:auto;}@media (max-width:425px){#sidepanel{width:7rem;max-width:7rem;}#sidepanel .nav-item,#sidepanel .nav-item a,#sidepanel footer a,#sidepanel div a,#sidepanel a span{font-size:10px;}#sidepanel ul,#sidepanel div{padding:0;margin:0;}#sidepanel button{display:none;}}</style>SearchMy RecipesSubscribeMembership BenefitsRecipesMealsHolidaysFood TrendsNewsKitchen Tips & ToolsAll VideosAbout UsNewsletterDelish ShopFollowOther EditionsYour Privacy ChoicesPrivacy NoticeTerms Of UseSkip to ContentRecipesDinnersSpring RecipesKitchen TipsNewsSubscribesign inSearchMeals & CookingRecipe HeadquartersCarrot Cake CupcakesCarrot Cake CupcakesBy Makinze GoreUpdated: Apr 9, 2025Approved by the Delish Test Kitchen4.52 RatingsParker Feierbach Yields: 18 serving(s)Prep Time:      25 minsTotal Time:    1 hr 45 minsCal/Serv: 429Jump to recipeSavePrintClassic carrot cake is a staple spring dessert, but if you donâ€™t have the time or energy to make a layer cake, then Iâ€™ve got you covered. With these cupcakes, I have transformed the beloved spice cake into a shareable treat. If youâ€™re serving a crowd this Easter, then these cupcakes are the best (and easiest) way to make sure everyone gets plenty of this sweet carrot-filled cake and its decadent cream cheese frosting. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know.What People Are Saying:"These were pretty delicious and easy to makeâ€¦.The flavor is on point because itâ€™s not too sweet. To top it off, the cream cheese frosting is AMAZING!" - Huong373"I am a beginner with cooking and baking and this was an absolute success for me. I followed the recipe, only replacing pecans with walnuts because I ran out. I brought them to an Easter gathering and everyone loved them! I will definitely be making this again." - BlueBeerHow To Make Carrot Cake CupcakesINGREDIENTSCUPCAKES       Flour: I went with all-purpose flour because it offers the ideal compromise between structure and tenderness. Unlike cake flour, which can make the cupcakes overly delicate, all-purpose flour ensures they bake up nice and tall yet remain moist and flavorful.       Spices: Itâ€™s not carrot cake without the warm spice notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. These spices infuse the cupcakes with an aromatic depth that perfectly complements the sweetness of the carrots.       Butter: Using room temperature butter is crucial to achieving a moist, tender crumb. The softened butter blends seamlessly into the batter, coating the proteins in the flour and thereby helping to prevent excessive gluten formation. When baking, I always use unsalted butter to control the salt content.       Granulated Sugar & Brown Sugar: I went with a 3:1 ratio of granulated sugar to brown sugar to achieve the best texture and flavor. The granulated sugar keeps the cupcakes light and airy, while the brown sugar keeps them moist and contributes a deep, caramel-like sweetness.        Eggs: Eggs add structure and stability and help the cupcakes bake up moist and fluffy. Be sure to use room temp eggs, which blend into the batter more evenly, resulting in a better rise.       Milk: Milk supplies moisture to help the cupcakes bake up soft and tender. I prefer to use whole milk, as its higher fat content results in cupcakes with a moister, more tender crumb.       Carrots: I know itâ€™s tempting to run out and buy a bag of pre-shredded carrots, but donâ€™t do it. Pre-shredded carrots have lost much of their moisture and that translates to drier, less tender cupcakes. Instead, grate peeled whole carrotsâ€”youâ€™ll only need 2 or 3â€”on the small holes of a box grater. Your cupcakes will thank you for it.        Pecans: Sweet, buttery pecans bring a satisfying crunch and offer a lovely complement to the warm spices. If pecans arenâ€™t your thing, swap in walnuts or simply omit the nuts.FROSTING       Cream Cheese: Cream cheese gives the frosting a rich, tangy flavor that offers a delicious contrast to the sweet cupcakes. Do plan ahead and give your cream cheese 30 minutes or so to come to room temperature; the resulting frosting will be far smoother and creamier.        Butter: Butter adds richness and gives the frosting a smooth, creamy texture that makes it perfect for spreading on the cupcakes.       Confectioners' Sugar: For a silky smooth buttercream, only confectioners' sugar will do. This finely milled sugar readily dissolves into the frosting, leaving no trace of graininess.       Cinnamon: I add a pinch of cinnamon to my frosting for a touch of spice warmth, but feel free to leave it out if you prefer. STEP-BY-STEP INSTRUCTIONS Alright, roll up your sleevesâ€”let's get to work! First things first, preheat your oven to 350Â°. You'll need 2 standard muffin tins, so go ahead and line them with cupcake liners. Now, grab a medium bowl and whisk together your dry ingredients: flour, salt, baking soda, cinnamon, and nutmeg. The key here is to whisk until everything is evenly distributed.PHOTO: CHELSEA LUPKINNow letâ€™s mix the wet ingredients. Youâ€™ll want an electric mixer for thisâ€”either a hand mixer and a large bowl or a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment will do. Beat together the room temperature butter and the sugars until light and fluffy; start on low speed and gradually increase to medium speed. Youâ€™ll know the butter and sugar are properly creamed when the mixture noticeably increases in volume and turns pale in color; expect this to take 3 to 5 minutes. Next, with the mixer running, add the eggs one at a time, beating until incorporated after each addition. Beat in the vanilla. Letâ€™s turn this into a batter. Add the dry ingredients to the wet and beat until just combined; donâ€™t overdo it, as overmixing can lead to dry cupcakes. Now add the milk and beat until combined. Turn off the mixer, grab a rubber spatula, and gently fold in the carrots and pecans just until combined. Distribute the batter evenly among the liners, filling about three-quarters full; I find a large cookie scoop works wonders for this. PHOTO: CHELSEA LUPKINBake the cupcakes until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean, about 20 minutes. Let them cool in the muffin tins for about 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack. Cooling on a wire rack is key as it allows air to circulate around the cupcakes, preventing them from becoming soggy and ensuring they cool evenly. Be sure to let the cupcakes cool completely before you frost them; otherwise, the frosting is apt to slide right off. While the cupcakes are cooling, letâ€™s tackle the frosting. Youâ€™ll want to make sure both the cream cheese and the butter are at room temperature. Youâ€™ll also want to clean and thoroughly dry the beaters from your mixer. All set? Great, combine the cream cheese and butter in a large bowl and beat until smooth and homogeneous. Add the confectioners' sugar and beat just until incorporated and the frosting is smooth and creamy; donâ€™t overmix or you risk warming the frosting, which could turn it loose or, worse, runny. Beat in the vanilla, cinnamon, and salt until just combined.PHOTO: CHELSEA LUPKINFit a piping bag with a large round tip, then transfer the frosting to the bag. To make this easier, I like to place the bag, tip down, in a large jar and then scoop the frosting into the bag with a spatula. Pipe the frosting onto the cooled cupcakes. Top with toasted pecans.PHOTO: CHELSEA LUPKINFull list of ingredients and directions can be found in the recipe below.Recipe Tips       The secret to moist cupcakes: When mixing your batter, mix until just combined. If you overmix, you run the risk of your cupcakes being dry rather than moist and tenderâ€”and nobody wants that.       How to top your cupcakes: I topped my cupcakes with toasted pecans, but you can leave them plain if you prefer, or top them however you like!Storage Once made, you can store these cupcakes in an airtight container in the fridge for 3 to 4 days.Read MoreAdvertisement - Continue Reading BelowIngredientsSee All Nutritional InformationPrintCupcakes2 cups (240 g.)Â all-purpose flourÂ 1 tsp. baking soda1 tsp. ground cinnamon1 tsp. kosher salt1/4 tsp. finely grated nutmegÂ 1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, softenedÂ 3/4 cup (150 g.)Â granulated sugarÂ 1/4 cup (55 g.)Â packed light brown sugar2 large eggs1 1/2 tsp. pure vanilla extract1/2 cup whole milk1 cup grated carrots (from about 2 medium)Â 3/4 cup toasted unsalted pecans, coarsely choppedÂ Frosting1 (8-oz.)Â pkg. cream cheese1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, softened4 cups (460 g.)Â confectioners' sugarÂ Â 1 tsp. pure vanilla extractÂ 1/2 tsp. ground cinnamonÂ 1/4 tsp. kosher saltFinely chopped toasted unsalted pecans, for servingEquipment NeededA piping bag, a large round tipDirectionsCupcakesStepÂ 1Arrange racks in upper and lower thirds of oven; preheat to 350Â°. Line 2 standard 12-cup muffin tins with liners. In a medium bowl, whisk flour, baking soda, cinnamon, salt, and nutmeg.StepÂ 2In a large bowl, using a handheld mixer on medium-high speed (or in the large bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment), beat butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs, one at a time, beating to blend after each addition, beat in add vanilla.StepÂ 3Add dry ingredients and beat on medium-low speed until just combined. Add milk and beat until combined, then fold in carrots and pecans. Fill liners three-quarters full with batter.StepÂ 4Bake cupcakes until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean, about 20 minutes. Let cool.FrostingStepÂ 1In a large bowl, using handheld mixer on medium-high speed (or in the large bowl of stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment) beat cream cheese and butter until no lumps remain. Add confectioners' sugar and beat until smooth, then add vanilla, cinnamon, and salt.StepÂ 2Transfer frosting to piping bag fitted with large round tip. Frost cupcakes. Top with pecans.Parker Feierbach LIKE THIS RECIPE? name: Meals & Cooking
ingredients: 2 c. (240 g.) all-purpose flour ;1 tsp. baking soda;1 tsp. ground cinnamon;1 tsp. kosher salt;1/4 tsp. finely grated nutmeg ;1 c. (2 sticks) unsalted butter, softened ;3/4 c. (150 g.) granulated sugar ;1/4 c. (55 g.) packed light brown sugar;2 large eggs;1 1/2 tsp. pure vanilla extract;1/2 c. whole milk;1 c. grated carrots (from about 2 medium) ;3/4 c. toasted unsalted pecans, coarsely chopped ;1 (8-oz.) pkg. cream cheese;1/2 c. (1 stick) unsalted butter, softened;4 c. (460 g.) confectioners' sugar  ;1 tsp. pure vanilla extract ;1/2 tsp. ground cinnamon ;1/4 tsp. kosher salt;Finely chopped toasted unsalted pecans, for serving;A piping bag, a large round tip
instructions: Meals & Cooking;Recipe Headquarters;Carrot Cake Cupcakes;StepÂ 1Arrange racks in upper and lower thirds of oven; preheat to 350Â°. Line 2 standard 12-cup muffin tins with liners. In a medium bowl, whisk flour, baking soda, cinnamon, salt, and nutmeg.;StepÂ 2In a large bowl, using a handheld mixer on medium-high speed (or in the large bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment), beat butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs, one at a time, beating to blend after each addition, beat in add vanilla.;StepÂ 3Add dry ingredients and beat on medium-low speed until just combined. Add milk and beat until combined, then fold in carrots and pecans. Fill liners three-quarters full with batter.;StepÂ 4Bake cupcakes until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean, about 20 minutes. Let cool.;StepÂ 1In a large bowl, using handheld mixer on medium-high speed (or in the large bowl of stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment) beat cream cheese and butter until no lumps remain. Add confectioners' sugar and beat until smooth, then add vanilla, cinnamon, and salt.;StepÂ 2Transfer frosting to piping bag fitted with large round tip. Frost cupcakes. Top with pecans.
